Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat at the edge of the pool, my phone propped up with the team meeting already in progress. My manager’s voice echoed through my earbuds, outlining project updates that I knew wouldn’t be repeated. I was expected to chime in, to show I was engaged and on top of things. But as I tried to focus, laughter and splashing caught my attention. A group of teenagers clustered near the deep end, daring each other to dive despite the bold red “NO DIVING” signs. My heart pounded. As a lifeguard, I was responsible for their safety, expected to intervene immediately and enforce the rules. But if I left the meeting, I’d miss crucial information and risk looking disengaged to my colleagues. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention at the exact same moment.
